title: B. Wayne Hughes Built a Self-Storage Empire. Now He Wants to Rent You a McMansion.
summary: Americans are giving suburban home rentals a new look as they search for affordable space during an economic downturn. A billionaire who made his fortune from storage facilities anticipated this moment nearly a decade ago.

title: Stocks Log Modest Weekly Gains
summary: The Dow and S&P 500 closed higher as investors brushed off worries about a fresh wave of coronavirus infections and its impact on the economic recovery.

title: Coronavirus’s Worst Impact on Oil Demand Has Passed, IEA Says
summary: The worst effects of the coronavirus on global oil demand have passed but will continue to echo as the market slowly recovers in the second half of 2020, the International Energy Agency said.

title: USDA Report: World Agricultural Supply and Demand Estimates
PE Daily: PE Deal Volume Plummets | Oaktree’s Airline Lifeline | Pandemic Alters Secondary Game
summary: Many U.S. readers may still be on vacation after the Independence Day holiday. For those at work, first-half fundraising and deal numbers are streaming in, and both are heading lower after the coronavirus brought travel to a halt and shifted deal-sourcing and due-diligence online. As Laura Cooper writes this morning, U.S. private-equity investments fell, with the dollar value of deals falling more sharply than the number of deals. Meanwhile, Oaktree Capital Management is offering a $1.3 billion bankruptcy lifeline to one of Latin America’s biggest airlines, and our latest survey of secondary investors illustrates how the pandemic quickly shifted buyer sentiment. Finally, Luis Garcia explains why the rebound in oil prices may not be enough to sustain private equity’s energy bets, even after many firms revamped their investment approach.

title: Garcia’s Take: Oil Still Hasn’t Rebounded Enough
summary: Most private equity-backed energy companies are having to turn profits by producing oil, instead of by exiting undeveloped fields.

title: Oxy’s Sweetener a Bitter Pill for Warren Buffett
summary: Occidental Petroleum’s surprise gift to shareholders such as Carl Icahn dents the value of the company’s lifeline from Berkshire Hathaway last year.

title: Newsletter: Growth Hinges on Containing Covid-19
summary: Your daily economics newsletter from The Wall Street Journal.

title: China’s Energy Policy Is a Darker Shade of Green
summary: China is simultaneously ramping up investment in both renewables and coal, raising uncomfortable questions for investors as well as climate activists

title: Goldbugs Take Center Stage in Markets, but the Real Show Is With Energy
summary: It’s getting harder to bet on a strong economic recovery. The wave of states opening back up has directly resulted in a wave of new coronavirus infections.

title: The Daily Shot: Sentiment Slumps Among Older Americans
America Is on a Lumber Binge
summary: Prices for forest products like lumber and plywood have soared because of booming demand from home builders making up for lost time, a DIY explosion and a race among restaurants and bars to install outdoor seating.

title: Libya, U.S. Probe Alleged Gold Trade Between Venezuela and Warlord
summary: Libya and the U.S. are investigating suspected gold-for-cash trades between Venezuela and Libyan militia leader Khalifa Haftar, security officials said.

title: PE Daily: BC Partners Pressed on PetSmart Safety | L.A. County Pension Seeks Co-Investments | Connecticut Taps Goldman | Bankruptcy Intrigue
summary: Amid the resurging coronavirus pandemic there’s no sign of the lazy days of summer, at least not from this perch 10 miles south of the New Hampshire state line. From dissatisfied workers at a BC Partners portfolio company to pension funds searching for better returns and a spate of fresh deals, both inside bankruptcy courts and out, we have been wading through a deluge of news.

title: Fed’s Bostic Less Optimistic as Virus Spreads; Rosengren Says Main Street Program Could Step Up If Economy Slumps
summary: Atlanta Fed leader Raphael Bostic said some of the better scenarios for the U.S. economy appear less likely as coronavirus cases surge in some parts of the U.S. “Some of the data might have me leaning towards less optimistic scenarios in terms of how much recovery there will be,” he said. Eric Rosengren of the Boston Fed struck a similar note, saying the Main Street Lending Program for midsize businesses—which has attracted little interest since its launch in April—will take on more importance if economic disruption from the pandemic continues for a long time.

title: Oil Went Below $0. Some Think It Will Rebound to $150 One Day.
summary: Crude markets began the 2020s by nosediving below $0 a barrel for the first time. Investors and analysts are now trying to work out what the rest of the decade holds in store.

title: Trump, López Obrador Tout Cooperation
summary: Presidents Donald Trump and Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico proclaimed their friendship while pledging to work together as neighbors on migration, trade and efforts to counter drug trafficking.

title: Bondholders Seek Probe of Bankrupt Sable Permian
summary: Bondholders with more than $700 million at risk in the bankruptcy of Sable Permian are calling for a court-ordered probe of suspected secret restructuring talks favoring the interests of the driller’s private-equity owners.

title: Gold ETF Inflows Hit Record as Bullion Rally Continues
summary: Nearly $40 billion flowed into gold-backed exchange-traded funds in the first half of the year, topping the previous annual record and highlighting robust investor demand for precious metals during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Libya’s Foul Foretaste of the Post-American World
summary: Amid the chaos, the EU, NATO and the Arab world are all divided over which warlords to support.

title: WSJ Wealth Adviser Briefing: Shale Gas, Investment Firms, Travel Threats
summary: The international trade in liquefied natural gas has collapsed and squeezed an important outlet for U.S. shale gas; investment firms and real-estate developers took stimulus loans, and the resurgence of coronavirus has threatened the travel rebound.

title: Visit by Mexican Leader Highlights Unlikely Friendship With Trump
summary: U.S. President Donald Trump and Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador will hold their first face-to-face meeting on Wednesday in Washington, D.C.

title: The World Can’t Take Much More Shale Gas
summary: Natural-gas prices have bounced back from the 25-year low reached late last month, but analysts and traders don’t expect them to go much higher. At least until it is time to turn on the heat.

title: Oil Prices Swing Ahead of Stockpile Data
summary: Crude prices have stalled around $40 a barrel as traders wait for inventory data that might indicate whether the U.S. economy and demand for oil are indeed rebounding.

title: Airlines Aren’t OPEC: Don’t Count on Supply Discipline
summary: Early trends suggest that airlines might be quite aggressive in bringing back their schedules, which would be a threat to profit margins.

title: She Found Herself by Souping Up Her Subaru
summary: A car lover found her calling after she decided to take improvements to her hand-me-down 2003 Impreza WRX into her own hands.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Lynn Tilton Found Liable in Transcare Failure | Pier 1 To Get New Life Online | Endologix Bondholders Face Wipeout
summary: A bankruptcy judge torched turnaround executive Lynn Tilton over her handling of Transcare, an ambulance company that collapsed into bankruptcy in 2016. Pier 1 Imports nabbed a stalking-horse offer for its online business and intellectual property, setting the stage for a modest comeback. And Deerfield Management’s proposed purchase of Endologix out of bankruptcy leaves little in the way of recovery for bondholders.

title: Bank Negara Malaysia Cuts Policy Rate to Record Low
summary: Malaysia’s central bank cut its benchmark interest rate to a record low in a bid to help the economy recover from the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Joe Biden’s First Energy Casualty
summary: Utilities pull the plug on a gas pipeline in a sign of damage to come.

title: Warren Buffett’s Bet Is a Midstream Buying Signal
summary: Berkshire Hathaway’s long-awaited pandemic-era purchase in a seemingly difficult business might seem like odd timing, but there is good logic behind it.

title: Dakota Access Pipeline Must Shut Down, Judge Rules
summary: A federal judge ordered the Dakota Access pipeline to shut down by next month because it was improperly granted a key environmental permit, a major setback for operator Energy Transfer LP and the American shale drilling industry.

title: Behind Oil’s Rise Is a Historic Drop in U.S. Crude Output
summary: U.S. crude supply is falling at its quickest pace ever, easing a global oil glut and spurring a swift recovery in fuel prices.

title: Fed’s Bostic Discusses Economic Toll of Systemic Racism; The Case for Putting Stimulus on Autopilot
summary: Raphael Bostic, the first Black president of one of the 12 regional reserve banks, is shining a light on how economic and social upheaval have changed how the Fed talks and thinks about racial and economic inequality. Meanwhile, as Congress gears up to debate another round of stimulus, some economists are saying enhanced unemployment benefits should be authorized to continue until the unemployment rate falls below a preset threshold, avoiding the political fights that can slow relief efforts.

title: Newsletter: Covid-19 Is Reshaping the Economy
summary: Your daily economics newsletter from The Wall Street Journal.

title: Why Investors Have Learned to Love Wind and Solar Power
summary: After a stormy, dependent youth, the wind-and-solar-energy industries have matured into boring, profitable middle age. This year’s plunging interest rates make that a more appealing proposition than ever for investors.

title: The Daily Shot: China’s Stock Market Soars as Beijing Encourages Buying
The Assets That Have Best Protected Investors Against Inflation
summary: The best way to figure it out is to look at historical correlations, writes a George Mason professor. Here’s what those numbers reveal.

title: How a Volatile Dollar Hurts Emerging Markets
summary: Emerging-markets investors need to pay attention when the dollar strengthens. It can lead to capital outflows and make debt more expensive to service in many developing economies.

title: China Is Unlikely to Meet Purchase Targets for U.S. Energy
summary: Economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic has cast doubt on whether China can meet its targets to buy U.S. goods under this year’s trade deal—with energy emerging as the biggest casualty.

title: Emerging and Growth Markets, July 4th 2020
summary: A weekly roundup of key news affecting emerging and growth markets from the Wall Street Journal and beyond.

title: Oil Crash Crushes Individual Investors, Prompts Trading Overhaul
summary: Many amateur investors got burned in an April price crash as some market professionals thrived, leading mutual-fund companies, traders and others to change their practices to try to prevent future collapses.

title: Gasoline Is Cheap This July Fourth. Fuel Retailers Aren’t Complaining.
summary: Drivers hitting the road over July Fourth weekend are poised to enjoy the cheapest holiday gasoline prices in years, but the gas stations are doing OK, too.

title: Dozens of U.S. Diplomats to Leave Saudi Arabia as Virus Outbreak Worsens
summary: A group of U.S. diplomats and their families are leaving Saudi Arabia this weekend amid a surge in new coronavirus cases, drawing into focus the kingdom’s struggle to contain the outbreak as it reopens its economy.

title: European Stocks Drift Lower With U.S. Markets Shut
summary: European stocks fell, with trading volumes down as American markets were shut for the Independence Day holiday and investors took stock of a surge in coronavirus infections in the U.S.

title: Copper Slips, Halting Sharp Rebound
summary: Copper prices fell, signaling a pause in the industrial metal’s surge, on mounting concerns that the rally may have been overdone.

title: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

title: Oil Prices Rise on Jobs Report
summary: Global crude prices rose Thursday after employment data showed the U.S. economy gained more jobs than expected last month.

title: Exxon Warns Production, Refining Losses to Hurt Earnings
summary: Exxon Mobil warned of steep losses in its refining and oil-and-gas production businesses during the second quarter, signaling that the company is likely to report a second straight quarterly loss later this month.

title: Lonestar Resources Skips $14 Million Interest Payment on Bonds
summary: The oil-and-gas producer, which recently raised doubts about its ability to survive, said it skipped a $14.1 million bond interest payment due Wednesday.

title: Today’s Logistics Report: YRC’s Big Bailout; Resetting Free Trade; Delivery on Ice
summary: Today’s Top Supply Chain & Logistics News from WSJ.

title: Putin’s Landslide Referendum Victory Is Slammed by Critics
summary: The day after a landslide vote that cemented President Vladimir Putin’s quest to prolong his stay in power for up to another 16 years, critics slammed the plebiscite as undemocratic, while supporters praised the results as validating his policies.

title: Fed Officials Grappled With Economic Uncertainty at June Meeting; U.K. Judge Rejects Maduro Claim for Venezuelan Gold at BOE
summary: Fed officials are in no hurry to remove the support they have provided the U.S. economy in recent months, to judge by the minutes of their meeting last month. The minutes also showed they made progress toward a consensus on a strategy to guide borrowing costs lower and that they grappled with extreme uncertainty and changes in economic conditions. Outside the U.S., a U.K. judge rejected a claim by Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro seeking the release of $1 billion of gold held in a Bank of England vault to finance coronavirus relief efforts.

title: Big Oil’s Slippery Strategies for a Greener Future
summary: However they tackle the energy transition, oil-and-gas supermajors risk wasting shareholder capital on projects that don’t pay back.

title: The Daily Shot: Biggest Monthly Increase in the ISM Manufacturing Index Since 1980
What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

title: S&P 500 Edges Up to Start Third Quarter
summary: The S&P 500 rose in the first session of July after data showed the labor market continued to improve last month.

title: Russians Vote for Overhaul That Could Keep Putin in Power Until 2036
summary: Russians voted overwhelmingly in preliminary results for constitutional changes to reset presidential term limits and give Vladimir Putin the chance to stay in office two more terms.

title: Oil Prices Climb After Inventory Data
summary: Prices are near their highest level since early March, buoyed by recovering fuel demand and supply cuts. Wednesday’s rally was supported by declining U.S. crude inventories and production.

title: Green Bonds Need the Right Filter
summary: The industry must not let its impressive growth undermine essential efforts to standardize what counts as green.

title: Saudis Threaten New Oil-Price War With OPEC Brethren
summary: Saudi Arabia has threatened to ignite an oil-price war unless fellow OPEC members make up for their failure to abide by the cartel’s recent production cuts.

title: PE Daily: EQT Eyes an Infrastructure Fund Record | Restaurants Find Saviors | TPG in Cirque du Soleil Tussle
summary: Today we have a look at EQT’s latest fundraising drive from our Laura Kreutzer, who says the new infrastructure pool would be the Stockholm firm’s largest if it reaches or surpasses its €12.5 billion target. Meanwhile, TPG and Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec are facing stiff resistance in a battle for control over Montreal’s Cirque du Soleil, Andrew Scurria and Miriam Gottfried report. Also, our colleague Aisha Al-Muslim on the WSJ Pro Bankruptcy team has an interesting account of restaurant companies recently driven into bankruptcy and how they’ve found suitors to pull them out.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Frac Sand Supplier Covia Files for Bankruptcy | Bankrupt Cirque du Soleil to Field Offers | Grupo Aeroméxico Files for Chapter 11
summary: Frac-sand suppliers have been hammered by the drop in energy prices and fallout from the Covid-19 pandemic. Now one of the biggest, Covia Holdings Corp., has filed for bankruptcy to slash $1 billion in debt from its books. Cirque du Soleil Entertainment Group is hoping its bankruptcy will settle an ownership feud between secured creditors and top shareholder TPG. And Mexican airline Grupo Aeroméxico SAB filed for chapter 11 protection in New York.

title: When Companies Prepare for Disaster, Investors Should Expect Lower Returns
summary: Investors who want to look beyond the day-to-day concerns of second lockdowns and the shape of economic recoveries should focus on one word: Resilience.

title: Chinese Oil Futures Draw More International Interest
summary: Foreign companies and investors are warming to Chinese oil futures, a boost to a project that Beijing hopes will strengthen the yuan’s appeal and loosen the dollar’s hold on global commodity pricing.

title: The Daily Shot: Over 40% of U.S. Population Has Seen Reopening Halted or Reversed
What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

title: Coronavirus Sends Oil Prices on Wild, Six-Month Ride
summary: U.S. crude’s 92% advance marks oil’s largest quarterly percentage gain in 30 years.

title: Exxon Mobil Resists Write-Downs as Oil, Gas Prices Plummet
summary: As its peers write down U.S. shale assets by billions of dollars amid lower energy prices, Exxon Mobil stands increasingly alone in not adjusting the value of its holdings, and some accountants are questioning why.

title: Frac-Sand Supplier Covia Files for Bankruptcy
summary: The Ohio company has filed for bankruptcy as part of a plan to cut more than $1 billion in debt and shed its railcar leases after taking a beating from the disruption sparked by the coronavirus pandemic and lower energy prices.

title: No End in Sight for Big Oil’s Write-Downs
summary: Stocks like Shell and BP are cheap because investors have to shoulder more risk for lower returns.

title: Shell Takes $22 Billion Write-Down, Expecting Lower Oil and Gas Prices
summary: Royal Dutch Shell is writing down the value of its assets by up to $22 billion because of lower energy prices following the demand-sapping coronavirus pandemic.

title: Denbury Resources Skips $8 Million Interest Payment on Notes
summary: The clock is ticking for shale driller Danbury Resources, which skipped an interest payment to bondholders.

title: PE Daily: Summit Raises Over $2.2 Billion | Rhode Island Invests Directly in VC | Wave of Corporate Failures Stays at Bay—for Now
summary: Just days after Congress loosened the Volcker Rule restricting balance-sheet investing by banks, the Supreme Court has further weakened the post-crisis Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act. The court held the law put too much authority in the leader of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, one of former Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren’s signature initiatives. In a 5-4 ruling, the court said the president can replace the director of the bureau for any reason. The 2010 Dodd-Frank measure put the Volcker rule into law and created the CFPB. But the court didn’t order the dismantling of the bureau.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Restaurants Find Buyers While Retail Languishes | Fast-food Franchisee NPC Preps for Chapter 11 | TPG Vies to Salvage Cirque du Soleil
summary: Not all brick-and-mortar is doomed, if restaurants are any indication, WSJ Pro Bankruptcy’s Aisha Al-Muslim reports. While bankrupt retailers have had difficulty finding buyers, investors are more optimistic that eateries can outlast the pandemic.

title: Who Says Emerging Economies Shouldn’t Print Money?
summary: Activist central banks aren’t just a rich-nation story anymore. Emerging markets are reclaiming their right to play with money too—and it is probably a good thing.

title: Fed Backstop Fueled Corporate Bond Surge
summary: The Fed’s intervention to cushion the economy this spring created an unusual paradox in the corporate bond market, with investors buying record amounts of new bonds from U.S. companies even as defaults and ratings downgrades surged.

title: Dollar’s Volatile Stretch Turns Into Tentative Calm
summary: The U.S. dollar has mirrored the swings in the stock market since the March selloff. Looking ahead, the outlook may be as murky for the currency as it is for the S&P 500 index.

title: Wave of Corporate Failures Stays at Bay—for Now
summary: Some on Wall Street are starting to wonder if the anticipated crush of corporate failures will ever arrive.

title: The Daily Shot: Current Hit to Household Net Worth Much Less Severe Than in 2008
Chesapeake Energy to Start Tapping $925 Million Bankruptcy Loan
summary: The oil-and-gas producer has been cleared to begin drawing on a $925 million bankruptcy loan, a crucial first step in its plan to eliminate billions of dollars of debt from its balance sheet in chapter 11.

title: Battery Metal Lithium Left Behind as Commodities Rebound
summary: Lithium has been left for dust during the rebound in commodity prices, but it could be poised to benefit from stimulus packages that aim to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions.

title: Q&A: What Does the Russia Vote Mean for Putin?
summary: Russians are heading to the polls in a vote that is expected to pave the way for President Vladimir Putin to remain in charge until 2036.

title: BP Exits Petrochemicals Business in $5 Billion Deal
summary: Energy giant BP has agreed to sell its petrochemicals business to British chemicals company Ineos for $5 billion, marking the largest deal by an oil major since the new coronavirus was declared a pandemic.

title: AGS WEEK AHEAD: USDA Reports Expected to Show Ample Grain Supplies
Lilis Energy Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
summary: Lilis Energy Inc. has filed for bankruptcy protection amid an oil- and gas-price rout stoked by the Covid-19 pandemic, which has hurt demand for fossil fuels

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Chesapeake Files to Cut $7 Billion Debt | Remington Eyes Bankruptcy Sale to Navajo | Creditors Question Sable Permian Governance
summary: Fracking pioneer Chesapeake Energy, which helped lead a rebirth of U.S. fossil-fuel output, filed for bankruptcy hoping to trim roughly $7 billion in debt. Firearms manufacturer Remington Arms is staring down the barrel at a chapter 22 bankruptcy and preparing to tap the Navajo Nation as a stalking horse bidder, WSJ Pro Bankruptcy reports exclusively. And Sable Permian, a West Texas fracker that has made a habit out of debt restructuring, is facing tough questions from creditors after filing for bankruptcy.

title: Apple, Verizon Among Beneficiaries of Fed’s Bond Purchases; Fed Looks Down Under for Rate Strategy
summary: Fed disclosures released Sunday showed that Apple, Verizon and the U.S. divisions of several foreign auto makers are among the largest direct beneficiaries of the central bank’s efforts to support the corporate-debt market. Meanwhile, as the Fed considers yield caps to help hold interest rates low amid the severe downturn, clues to the tactic’s effectiveness can be found in Australia. And American shoppers opened their pocketbooks last month, but a surge of new coronavirus cases could lead to new restrictions on commerce.

title: Newsletter: How Will Consumers Respond to New Coronavirus Cases?
summary: Your daily economics newsletter from The Wall Street Journal.

title: U.S. Is Vulnerable to China’s Dominance in Rare Earths, Report Finds
summary: China sees its dominance in strategic rare-earth minerals as leverage that can be used against the West—including in trade disputes with the U.S., according to a new report by U.S.-based researchers.

title: The Daily Shot: Investors Hedge Against a Potential Inflation Shock

summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

title: Fracking Trailblazer Chesapeake Energy Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Chesapeake Energy filed for bankruptcy protection as an oil- and gas-price rout stoked by the coronavirus pandemic proved to be the final blow for a shale-drilling pioneer long hamstrung by debt.

title: Emerging and Growth Markets, June 27th 2020
summary: A weekly roundup of key news affecting emerging and growth markets from the Wall Street Journal and beyond.

title: Sable Permian Files for Bankruptcy Amid Restructuring Talks
summary: Out-of-court restructurings kept the oil-and-gas operator afloat for years, but 2020 proved too much.

title: Pandemic’s Economic Toll Forces Egypt to Turn Again to IMF for Help
summary: Egypt’s economy is reeling as the coronavirus pandemic keeps tourists away, erodes remittances and undercuts spending by Egyptians whose wages were already depressed due to recent years of government austerity.

title: Covid-19 Is a Puzzle That Wall Street Can’t Solve
summary: A pandemic ended a U.S. bull market and pushed the financial system to the brink of collapse. Then stocks rallied, only to stall again. Investors are still piecing together what happened.

title: Frac-Sand Supplier Hi-Crush Negotiating Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
summary: Hi-Crush Inc., which supplies oil and gas companies with sand used in fracking, is negotiating the terms of a chapter 11 bankruptcy with lenders following a sudden decline in business stemming from plunging crude prices and disruption from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Oil Prices Fall as Rising Covid-19 Cases Prompt Demand Concerns
summary: Oil prices edged lower Friday to cap the second weekly decline since April, as investors adjusted expectations to account for rising crude inventories and surging U.S. coronavirus cases.

title: Russian Fighters Help Tighten Rebel Control of Libya’s Largest Oil Field
summary: Mercenaries connected to the Russian government have joined forces with a rebel militia to hold Libya’s largest oil field, European and Libyan officials said, prompting U.S. protests over foreign interference in the country’s most strategic industry.

title: Today’s Logistics Report: Picking up the Last Mile; Charging for Inventory; Wine Imports Corked
summary: Today’s Top Supply Chain & Logistics News from WSJ.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Hertz Liquidation Rattles ABS Lenders | PG&E Raises More Than $5 Billion | Judge OKs Windstream Chapter 11 Exit Plan | Jason Industries Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Asset-backed securities investors are balking at what they call Hertz Global Holdings Inc’s assault—a bankruptcy bid to dump more than 25% of its rental fleet—on their securitization structure. PG&E Corp. said it expects to net more than $5 billion to help fund its emergence from chapter 11 bankruptcy.

title: Is Hydrogen the New Wonder Fuel?
summary: Technology to realize the vast potential of hydrogen is solid, but investors may be too far ahead of the adoption curve.

title: The Daily Shot: U.S. Consumers Reignite the Pandemic After Returning to the “Social Sector” of the Economy
Stocks Climb at End of Rocky Session
summary: U.S. stocks climbed, led by shares of banks, which rose on a regulator’s decision to ease some post-financial crisis requirements.

title: Evans Says Fed May Need to Do More for U.S. Economy; Canada Loses Its Triple-A Rating; IMF Outlook Gets Gloomier
summary: The Federal Reserve and U.S. government may need to step up and do more to help the economy recover from the effects of the coronavirus pandemic, Chicago Fed President Charles Evans said Wednesday. “The situation demands strong fiscal and monetary policy actions to help support households and businesses,” he said, adding that interest rates likely will stay low for a long time. Meanwhile, the effects of the pandemic delivered a blow on Wednesday to Canada’s triple-A credit rating, which Fitch Ratings lowered, and prompted the IMF to downgrade its outlook for the global economy this year.

title: Blackstone’s James Says Pandemic Window of Opportunity Closed Quickly
summary: The chance to bargain-hunt after March’s market crash lasted just two weeks, in contrast to nearly a year during the financial crisis, the buyout executive notes.

title: The Daily Shot: Entering the Slow Phase of the Recovery
Sugar Is Set for Best Quarter Since 2016, but Outlook Remains Murky
summary: Sugar prices are poised for their best quarter in four years, driven by a recovery in oil markets and supply disruptions in the market for the sweetener. But traders say the rally may not last.

title: Stock-Market Surge Masks Volatility in Individual Sectors
summary: The S&P 500 is on track for its best quarter since 1998, but despite the dramatic rebound, many sectors are still struggling to find steady footing.

title: Soybean Prices Rally as China Ramps Up Buying
summary: China has ramped up its purchases of U.S. soybeans recently, sparking a rebound in prices and making the crop profitable again for U.S. farmers after the coronavirus pandemic had slammed demand.

title: How Coronavirus Complicated the Quest for a Greener Plastic Bottle
summary: The effort to make greener plastic bottles—the core of beverage giants’ sustainability quest—has become harder and more expensive in the pandemic.

title: PE Daily: Carlyle Gauges ESG Impact | New Pledge for Oaktree | Endeavour Nets R.I. Investment | Charlesbank Joins TA and Vista in Backing Aptean
summary: Few taxpayers love the IRS, but you have to give the agency credit for pushing back the filing and quarterly payments deadline by three months this year because of the dislocations and disruptions caused by the coronavirus pandemic. And it may extend the timeframe even more. While governments and health officials wrestle with restarting the economy and the threat of a second wave of the virus, the possible extension is just another sign of how weird things still are. A walk along the somnolent avenues of New York’s Hell’s Kitchen on Monday afternoon provided yet another indication that we’re definitely not out of the woods yet.

title: Equatorial Guinea Adopts New Rules to Woo Oil and Gas Investors
Templar Energy Gets $65 Million Stalking-Horse Bid From Tapstone
summary: Shale driller Tapstone Energy, which recently completed a $450 million debt restructuring, is offering $65 million as the lead bidder to buy the assets of Templar Energy out of bankruptcy.

title: Oaktree’s New Distressed-Debt Fund Gets New Mexico Pledge
summary: Oaktree Capital Management has received a $100 million commitment from New Mexico’s sovereign-wealth funds for a distressed-debt fund that would be the largest ever raised, if the investment firm hits its $15 billion target.

title: Petroleum Refiners Pose Hurdle to Oil’s Recovery
summary: The recovery has lifted shares of energy companies and relieved some of the stress on oil-dependent economies such as Russia and Saudi Arabia. It is also squeezing profits at refiners, crimping a key source of demand for crude and potentially preventing prices from marching much higher.

title: GIP, Brookfield Invest $10 Billion in Abu Dhabi Gas Infrastructure
summary: The consortium will acquire a 49% stake in gas pipelines operated by the United Arab Emirates’ national oil company, a deal that marries yield-hungry funds with a country battered by low oil prices and the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Five States Energy to Close Fund Below $50 Million Target
summary: Five States Energy Capital has raised more than $20 million for a new fund to back working interests in oil wells, but waning investor interest in energy, a short fundraising timeline and concern about leadership succession at the firm hindered its progress.

title: Saudi Arabia Shrinks Hajj Pilgrimage Because of Coronavirus Pandemic
summary: Saudi Arabia said it was curtailing this year’s hajj pilgrimage to only a small number of people already in the kingdom, rather than the millions who usually flock to Islam’s holiest sites, amid concerns about the spread of the new coronavirus.

title: Gold Prices Near New Peak Amid Virus Uncertainty
summary: The precious-metal’s price neared a 7½-year high as the recent rise in coronavirus cases lifted demand for the haven asset.

title: Rally in Raw Materials Signals Economic Rebound
summary: Prices for raw materials including oil and copper are surging as the world economy reopens for business, a signal to many investors that global growth is returning more quickly than anticipated.

title: Chevron’s Saudi-Kuwait Venture Plans Restart Exports in July
summary: Chevron is set to resume oil exports in July from a long-dormant operation it shares with the governments of Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, oil officials said.

title: Bank of Canada Governor Focuses on Deflationary Pressure
summary: The Bank of Canada is unlikely to reduce the extraordinary stimulus it is providing to the economy in the near future as policy makers try to avoid a persistent decline in inflation, Governor Tiff Macklem said.

title: Weary Russia Tries to Avoid Entanglement in U.S.-China Spat
summary: With the coronavirus pandemic escalating the conflict between Washington and Beijing, Moscow faces a tough challenge: how to preserve its Chinese lifeline without getting dragged into the looming clash.

title: PE Daily: Carlyle-Oak Launch Insurance Venture | Illinois TRS Pledges Around $1.23 Billion | Endicott Advances on Debut Fund
summary: In the private-equity world, the week starts off with news of a joint venture in the insurance sector between Carlyle Group and Oak Hill Capital. As our own Ted Bunker reports, the two firms have launched Galway Insurance Holdings and are putting two of their existing portfolio companies into the new company.

title: Powell Speaks on Inequalities; Rosengren Upbeat on Main Street Facility; Russia’s Central Bank Slashes Key Rate to Post-Soviet Low
summary: Fed Chairman Jerome Powell on Friday said the economic shock caused by the coronavirus pandemic had exposed a range of “troubling inequalities,” most of which predated the current crisis. Separately, Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren pushed back at optimism that the economy may be rebounding faster than was expected. But he offered an upbeat update on the central bank’s Main Street lending facility: “We are seeing tremendous interest in the loans from businesses.” Elsewhere, Russia’s central bank cut its key rate by 1 percentage point and suggested more cuts may be in store.

title: Newsletter: Raw Materials Rally Signals Quicker Recovery
summary: Your daily economics newsletter from The Wall Street Journal.

title: The Daily Shot: The Stock Market Continues to Ignore Looming U.S. Political Risks
Emerging and Growth Markets, June 20th 2020
summary: A weekly roundup of key news affecting emerging and growth markets from the Wall Street Journal and beyond.

title: Maersk Tankers Changes Course in Volatile Oil Markets
summary: The company is offloading dozens of product tankers into a shared pool arrangement and transferring their ownership to a separate entity as it seeks to move from operating its own ships to a potentially more stable business of managing shipping arrangements.

title: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

title: Stocks End Mostly Lower as Apple Closes Stores
summary: U.S. stocks gave up gains to end lower after Apple said it is closing some stores in Florida, Arizona and other states due to a rise in coronavirus cases, stoking fears of another lockdown.

title: Oil Prices Rise on Demand Hopes
summary: Oil prices climbed, sending U.S. crude back near $40 a barrel with traders hopeful that global fuel demand will rebound more quickly than anticipated.

title: May’s U.S. Jobs Rebound Was Widespread
summary: Nearly all states added jobs last month as business reopenings allowed most areas of the country to start recovering from huge employment losses endured earlier in the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Russia Cuts Interest Rates to Post-Soviet Low
summary: Russia’s central bank slashed its benchmark interest rate to a post-Soviet low as the economy enters a deep recession fueled by the fall in oil prices and the coronavirus pandemic.

title: PE Daily: Ares Raises $3.19 Billion So Far for Sixth PE Fund | Chisholm Energy Files for Chapter 11 | AMC Lenders Push Back
summary: Many across the country will be commemorating Juneteenth marking the end of slavery in the United States. As The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday, a small but growing number of companies are declaring the day a corporate holiday for their employees.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Hertz in Talks With Lenders for DIP Loan | Private Equity-Backed Chisholm Oil & Gas Files for Bankruptcy | Talen Energy-Owned Power Plants File for Chapter 33
summary: Hertz Global Holdings Inc. is in talks for a $1 billion bankruptcy loan to fund its rental car business after calling off the controversial sale of its potentially worthless stock, writes WSJ’s Alexander Gladstone and Nora Naughton. Oklahoma-based shale driller Chisholm Oil & Gas Operating LLC, backed by private-equity sponsors Apollo Global Management LLC and Ares Management LLC, filed for bankruptcy with a deal to cut $517 million from its balance sheet. And a pair of Northeast power plants now owned by Talen Energy Corp. is back in bankruptcy for the third time in six years.

title: Shale Driller Chisholm Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
summary: Private-equity-owned Chisholm Oil & Gas has become the latest shale driller to file for bankruptcy, pushed into chapter 11 by a decline in commodity prices and production challenges in Oklahoma.

title: Marathon in Talks With Potential Buyers of Speedway Unit
summary: Marathon Petroleum is in discussions with potential buyers of its Speedway gas-station unit, reviving a sale that fell apart in the early stages of the coronavirus crisis.

title: Stocks Waver as Investors Track Rise in Coronavirus Cases
summary: The Dow and S&P 500 wavered as investors weighed a rise in coronavirus infections in some states against signs of stabilization in the labor market.

title: Oil Prices Rise Amid Supply Cuts
summary: Oil prices climbed Thursday, nearing their highest levels since early March with traders expecting supply cuts to help balance the crude market.

title: The Daily Shot: Mortgage Refinance Activity Remains Elevated as Rates Hover Near Record Lows
Norway’s Norges Bank Leaves Key Rate Unchanged At Zero
summary: Norway’s central bank kept its key interest rate at zero Thursday, as expected, and reaffirmed that it will likely remain at the current level for the next couple of years.

title: Dow Industrials Fall, Snapping 3-Day Winning Streak
summary: Investors weighed signs of the economy recovering against a rise in coronavirus infections in the U.S. and China.

title: Wheat Hits 8-Month Low on Strong Crops, Better Weather
OPEC Sticks to Global Oil-Demand Forecast Despite Signs of Rebound
summary: The global oil market is slowly starting to rebalance thanks to production cuts and relaxing coronavirus lockdowns, but the industry is still swimming in excess supply, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries said.

title: Canada’s Annual Inflation Rate Declined in May
summary: The consumer-price index fell 0.4% in May, reinforcing concerns about deflationary pressure as the economy recovers from shutdowns caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Oil Demand Is Headed for Record Rebound in 2021
summary: Supply cuts from producers and a record rebound in demand next year will help to rebalance the oil market from the shocks incurred during the coronavirus pandemic, the International Energy Agency said.

title: Rockets Fired Into Baghdad Airport Complex Used by U.S.-Led Coalition
summary: Rockets landed inside the Iraqi capital’s airport complex early Tuesday, the latest in a spate of recent attacks on facilities hosting U.S. personnel that threaten to undermine efforts to mend frayed ties between Washington and Baghdad.

title: PE Daily: Capitol Peak, KKR Win Borden Auction | Skillsoft Bankruptcy | AgroFresh Lands $150 Million
summary: The week is kicking off with a wave of restructuring news that sometimes has private-equity firms on both sides of the negotiating table.

title: Powell Goes Back Before Congress as Fed Unveils New Details on Bond Buying, Helping Nonprofits; BOJ Holds Policy Steady
summary: Fed Chairman Jerome Powell returns to Congress this morning to testify after a four-month interval in which the central bank has redefined its role in supporting the U.S. economy. His testimony comes on the heels of the Fed saying it would create a corporate bond portfolio as part of its bond-buying program. It also outlined a plan to include nonprofit organizations in its $600 billion lending program for small and midsize businesses. Outside the U.S., the Bank of Japan held policy steady while it observes the effects of its own program of support for companies hit by the coronavirus.

title: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

title: Chesapeake Misses Interest Payment, Starts Bankruptcy Countdown
summary: Chesapeake Energy is preparing to file for bankruptcy in as soon as a week after the pioneering shale driller missed an interest payment due on Monday, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Fed Will Amass Corporate Bond Portfolio Using Index Approach
summary: The central bank announced a buying scheme to complement existing purchases in exchange-traded funds.

title: Oil Prices Rise After Fed Updates Bond-Buying Program
summary: Oil prices climbed Monday, shooting higher after the Federal Reserve said in the afternoon that it will update its purchases of corporate bonds to include individual bonds in addition to exchange-traded funds.

title: Extraction Oil & Gas Files for Chapter 11 After Executive Payouts
summary: The Denver-based company has become the latest oil-and-gas driller to file for bankruptcy after handing out retention bonuses to top management and putting creditors in position to take over the business.

title: BP Is Writing Down Oil Projects. Dividends May Be Next.
summary: Impairments of up to $17.5 billion make it more likely the dividend will be cut and hint that the oil major’s green ambitions are serious.

title: BP Takes $17.5 Billion Write-Down, Expects Oil Price to Stay Low
summary: BP is writing down as much as $17.5 billion of its assets and might leave some of its oil and gas in the ground because of lower energy prices and weakened demand amid the global crisis caused by the novel coronavirus.

title: Electricity Looking Hot, Hot, Hot in Texas
summary: Texas is expected to be one of the only major U.S. power markets with higher electricity demand this summer, which bodes for an exciting few months for some energy companies.

title: Banks Cut Shale Drillers’ Lifelines
summary: Banks are slashing credit lines to shale drillers, as an oil-price crash and wells that have failed to produce as much as predicted force a painful reassessment of companies’ assets.

title: The Daily Shot: Risk-Off Sentiment Is Back, as Concerns About COVID-19 Progress Resurface
WSJ Wealth Adviser Briefing: Party Stalls, Auto Makers, Market Gamble
summary: The party in the market his a hiatus; auto makers in lockdown implemented a new car-buying experience, and playing the market has taken on a whole new meaning.

title: Economy Week Ahead: Central Banks, Industrial Production, Retail Sales
summary: Indicators are expected to provide insight into the state of the pandemic-induced economic turmoil around the world as Fed Chairman Jerome Powell is on tap to testify before Congress.

title: Investor’s Attack on Texas Lender Boomerangs
summary: Hayman Capital won big in betting against United Development Funding, but its relentless criticism of the Texas real-estate lender is now under regulatory scrutiny.

title: Frustrated Stock-Market Skeptics Stick With Cautious Bets
summary: Many investors remain skeptical the stock market’s powerful ascent can continue and are maintaining their cautious stances, a sign of lingering unease that could challenge the rally in the weeks ahead.

title: China a Bright Spot for U.S. in Global Trade
summary: China has retaken its mantle as America’s largest trading partner, emerging as a rare bright spot for U.S. farmers and other exporters as the pandemic limits global commerce.

title: Stocks Regain Strength, but Finish Week Lower
summary: The Dow and S&P 500 rose more than 1% following the biggest rout in the stock market since mid-March. But it wasn’t enough to prevent shares from falling for the week.

title: Aluminum Glut Revives Financial Crisis-Era Storage Trade
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic has revived interest in hoarding aluminum to sell at a later date, a trade that became controversial after the 2008-2009 financial crisis.

title: ‘Volatility Is Everywhere’: The Market Tactic That’s Driving Stocks Haywire
summary: Wild stock swings have lured investors big and small into the risky world of volatility trading. They’re wagering hundreds of billions of dollars on the strategy, which has grown so big that trading on expected market moves can itself move markets.

title: The Comfort of Eggs in a Time of Stress
summary: Unshowy dishes like egg salad, omelets and French toast are easy to make and evoke memories of a simpler age.

title: U.S. Stocks End Sharply Lower as Coronavirus Worries Return
summary: Growing fears of a spike in coronavirus infections in the U.S. sent the stock market tumbling, pulling the Dow industrials down 1,862 points, its worst day since punishing selloffs in March.

title: A Scramble for Gold Is Redrawing the Map of the Market
summary: New York faces a gold rush after the coronavirus pandemic threw precious-metal markets into disarray, setting off a scramble by traders to cut their losses.

title: How CEOs See Today’s Coronavirus World
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic is altering how the world operates. Here is how the leaders of Zoom, Walmart and Campbell Soup, among others, are describing the changes they are seeing.

title: Canvas Capital Sees Opportunity | Mass PRIM on Pandemic and PE | Impact Investors Gauge Contagion
summary: Good day. Following weeks of protests over the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis, some private-equity firms are promising to do more to help eliminate racism and social injustice. Read about such efforts and more.

title: Argentine Farmers, President Clash Over Government Seizure
summary: Argentina’s leftist government is moving to seize one of the country’s leading agricultural companies, Vicentin, putting President Alberto Fernández in direct conflict with the powerful farming sector.

title: Investors Get Ready for the Fed to Cap Rates
summary: Investors are preparing for the Federal Reserve to tap a policy tool untouched since the aftermath of World War II, a move that could change how key financial markets behave and give an even bigger boost to the stock market’s best performers.

title: Coronavirus Lands Founders and CEOs in the Customer Service Seat
summary: The coronavirus pandemic dealt Farmgirl Flowers one problem after another: A shelter-in-place order in March forced it to shut down its San Francisco distribution center and when customers asked about the delays, only 2 customer service employees were available. So responding often fell to Christina Stembel, the founder and chief executive officer.

title: The Daily Shot: Near-Zero Rates Are Here to Stay
Hit Hard by Coronavirus, Russia Joins Global Race for a Vaccine
summary: Russia is deploying its military and pushing the private sector to deliver on President Vladimir Putin’s demand for a vaccine by the fall, a race likened to the 1960s space race.

title: Private-Equity-Backed Vista Proppants Files for Bankruptcy
summary: The frac-sand supplier backed by investment firms First Reserve and Ares Capital has filed for bankruptcy, saying it is facing unprecedented problems due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: U.S. Stocks Waver After Fed Statement
summary: U.S. stocks slumped back toward their morning lows, even after the Federal Reserve projected no interest-rate increases through 2022.

title: Oil Prices Defy Supply-Demand Fundamentals
summary: Rather than surging on supply and demand fundamentals, oil prices have ridden along with other risky assets, such as stocks. Analysts and traders worry the rebound has been too sharp and could prove short-lived.

title: FOMC: Powell’s Conference, Economic Forecasts to Shed Light on Fed’s Thinking
summary: The Federal Open Market Committee wraps up its 2-day meeting today. While Fed officials haven’t locked themselves into a fixed pace of asset purchases, Chairman Jerome Powell has an opportunity at his press conference to clarify the Fed’s bond-buying intentions. And with rates unlikely to go lower, another major element of officials’ policy stance will center on how to communicate their long-run intentions with forward guidance. The Fed will also release economic forecasts for the first time since December, having skipped its usual forecast in March amid uncertainty over the impact of the coronavirus.

title: Trash Burning Ignites as World’s Waste Swells
summary: The growth of incineration, buoyed by moves against landfills, is raising concerns about fumes and impact on recycling efforts.

title: China’s Factory-Gate Deflation Accelerates
summary: Industrial prices fell at their fastest pace in more than four years as the coronavirus pandemic crushed global demand for commodities.
